context: Act 2B Chapter 2.1 — Detective Reyes approaches. Warning or recruitment as informant.

lines.text: A parking lot. Late. You are checking your phone after a practice run on the harbor circuit when headlights pin you against the wall.
An unmarked sedan. The kind that screams 'law enforcement' by trying not to scream anything at all. The engine dies. The door opens.

Detective Elena Reyes. Mid-forties. A face that has seen everything and decided to keep fighting anyway. Badge on her belt, not her chest — the placement of someone who uses authority as a tool, not a shield.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Don't run. If I wanted to arrest you, I would have done it at the race instead of waiting in a parking lot like a creep.
She leans against her car. Crosses her arms. Studies you with the patience of someone who interrogates people for a living.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: I know what you do at night. I know the circuits, the meets, the entry fees. I know about The Pit, the harbor runs, the industrial loop. I probably know more about the underground than most of its participants.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: And before you ask — no, I'm not here to shut it down. If I shut down every underground race in Nova Pacifica, I'd need a hundred officers and a thousand hours and the races would start again the next week in a different zip code.

choices.text: I don't know what you're talking about.
If you're not arresting me, I'm leaving.

lines.label: reyes_pitch
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Someone is moving serious weight through the underground racing scene. Not drugs — money. Clean money going in dirty, dirty money coming out clean. The races are being used as a laundering operation.

lines.label: reyes_amused
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Right. And the tire marks on Pier 7 drew themselves. And the noise complaints from Industrial Row every Saturday night are just 'ambient construction.'

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Drop the act. I'm here because we want the same thing — to keep the underground from being destroyed by something bigger than either of us.

lines.label: reyes_stops
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Wait.
Not a command. A request. There is something in her voice that doesn't belong to a detective — something almost desperate.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Five minutes. Give me five minutes and then you can go. But if you leave without hearing what I have to say, you're going to wish you'd stayed.

lines.label: reyes_details
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: There's a network operating above the street-level races. It uses the underground as infrastructure — the meets, the cash flows, the informal economy. Millions of dollars moving through race entries, side bets, vehicle sales.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: The person running it — or the entity, because my intelligence is unclear on whether it's a person or an organization — goes by 'Zero.'
Zero. Again. Always Zero.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: I've been building a case for two years. I'm close. But I need eyes inside the underground. Someone who races, who has access, who can get me information I can't get with a badge.

choices.text: You want me to be an informant.
The underground has a code. No snitching. Ever.

lines.label: reyes_confirms
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: I want you to be a concerned citizen who occasionally shares observations with law enforcement. The terminology is flexible.

choices.text: I'll keep my eyes open. But I'm not wearing a wire.

lines.label: reyes_respects
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: The code. I respect that. It's more than most organizations in this city have.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: But here's what the code doesn't account for: Zero doesn't follow it. Zero uses the underground and discards it. When I finally move on Zero, the underground is going to be collateral damage. Everyone. Every circuit. Every driver.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Help me take down Zero surgically, and the underground survives. Force me to use a sledgehammer, and everything Diesel built goes with it.

lines.label: reyes_offer
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Full immunity for any racing-related offenses. Past and future. A clean record. And when we take Zero down, you're on the right side of history instead of the wrong side of a jail cell.

choices.text: Keep your immunity. I'll handle Zero my own way.

lines.label: reyes_deal
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Your terms. I'm listening.

You establish boundaries. No names of regular drivers. No disrupting legitimate underground events. No raids based on your information without advance warning. The underground survives — that's the deal.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: Accepted. I'll be in touch. Use the burner number on the card.

lines.label: reyes_card
lines.text: Reyes pulls a card from her jacket. Simple. Just a phone number.

lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: When Zero comes for you — and they will — this number works. Day or night.
She gets back in her car. The engine starts. The headlights sweep across the parking lot.

lines.label: law_end
lines.speaker: Reyes
lines.text: One more thing. Diesel — tell him I said hello. He'll know who I am.
The sedan disappears. You stand in the parking lot holding a card that might be a lifeline or a noose. In the underground, the line between the two is thinner than a racing line.
